content.description: Climb up arete using good under clings and large crest, but be light on your feet it flex's but I could not break it when I tried.
content.location: back side of godfather same starting area as call in the cleaners but climbs up instead of right.

content.description:
On-Sight Beta:   Begin matched on the Godfather start. Climb into, then up the blunt arete between GF and The Good Times Are Killing Me. 

  Flash Beta:    Move up and away from God Father via gastons/side-pulls on the arete's right side. Established at the base of the arete, the crux works through left-hand crimpers/pinches from a high right-hand crimp/pinch, culminating in a semi dynamic dead-point. Jug layback to the top.

Start on the horn from "All in the Family" go to seam or slopey crimp to the left, then up with left hand farther up and left to slopey crimp hold with a thumb catch, foot up near right hand and press up. go to small seam that runs along just under where rock turns vertical, match and up to the lip.

climbs.name: The Good Times are Killing Me

content.description:
You can't miss this line on the north side of the big boulder.  Look for the set of solitary pockets out on the face.   Then look at how perfectly smooth the wall is below them.  

  Start out on the boulder to the right of the pockets.  With a right hand side pull on the arete, hop up into the pockets and get established.  A small foot pocket way out left will let you pop up to the lip.  Climb into the shallow trough.  Pretty fun and just steep enough to be really enjoyable. 

  You can also climb up the left arete to a couple of deep pockets and then move out the pockets on the face.  About the same difficulty.

One of the most recognizable classics in the park, this line was first cleaned and bouldered by Dave Groth in the mid eighties. Early repeats by John Sherman and Eric Zschiesche, during their Stone Crusade tour in the early 90's.

 This tall, steep, beautiful problem hosts an awesome series of side pull and gaston pockets. The movement flows well with a wide selection of footholds and positive handholds while steadily growing harder until the lip which sports a rather thoughtful mantle. It ain’t over until you're standing up.

A sort of compilation of a few lines.  Starts on the very bottom portion of the arete right of the "Godfather" line on pockets.  Cross right hand up to a two finger dish, and left hand move to an sidepull/undercling on the other side of the arete.  Shimmy up the arete to the crip rail, and transition onto Cosa Nostra. Top-out on good jugs.
content.protection: The more pads the better. Same with spotters.

content.description: Start on crimps about head height just left of the arete.  Work up the tall face using small holds while avoiding the arete until you can reach the jugs at the top.
content.protection: Pretty tall, the landing is pretty flat but there could be potential for falling off the boulder at the base.

content.description: goes straight up the corner to the left of 'the good times are killing me'

Start on arete and traverse right to center of face and climb up to lip. Be care full of the good features up high they need more climbing to see if any more are going to break. I did not step on any of them for fear of them breaking.
content.location: Back side of godfather boulder, arete with a low rock behind it.

content.description: Starts on easy corner problem, into good pods from 'the good times are killing me' then goes out right to break in the rock. match and then up and right on what could be fragile pockets, so be careful when up there. word

A long line that starts out in the hole and works up separate features to join Godfather at the top. Sharp low holds for the sit down lead to a pointed jug. With low left undercling reach up and hit the first in a series of slopers. Work left to a positive undercling rail and the crux. Follow that sucka to the top through more crimps, pockets, and flakes. A true classic for the park.

Perhaps 35 feet or so of continous bouldering at solid 5.12 climbing. Something like that. Start way down on the right side of the big boulder on steep arete at some really good pockets. Work up the arete using whatever feels good to the corner. Get a little rest and then start into the left tending traverse over crimps and slopers to the pointed jug on All In The Family, and continue to the top of that route.
The best boulder in the park.  Huge, overhanging, intimidating and super good.  Getting down requires downclimbing an easy arete, jumping onto stacked pads, or dry humping the curving tree.
